repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Tianjin Urban Development
            and Environment Project and Chongqing Small Cities
            Infrastructure Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Tianjin Urban
            Development and Environment Project for China were as
            follows: outcome was moderately unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was negligible or low, Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Ratings for the Chongqing Small
            Cities Infrastructure Improvement Project for China were as
            follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was significant, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            great care is needed in project preparation and appraisal to
            ensure that all interventions are feasible. A well-phrased
            and clearly defined project development objective statement
            and a comprehensive monitoring and evaluation (M and E)
            framework is a key step towards a results-focused Bank
            operation. By continuing to tailor its services and
            instruments to the more localized needs and capacity of the
            Borrower, the Bank can maintain the effectiveness of its
            support. While the Bank's engagement has supported the
            development in China, its prolonged internal decision-making
            processes may decrease its competitiveness in helping
            address fast-paced changes.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Tianjin Urban Development
            and Environment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Tianjin Urban
            Development and Environment Project for China were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low risk, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the project involved adopting approaches and technologies
            which had been practiced relatively infrequently around the
            world, and of which there were no or few successful
            experiences in China. These were: polluted/toxic sediment
            disposal (in Dagu Canal), small town urban sewerage
            (including the Design-Build-Operate, or DBO method),
            wastewater reuse, and bus priority corridors. The first two
            were successfully implemented as originally planned, but at
            considerable costs. Both required a large amount of
            high-level input for preparation and implementation, and the
            DBO for Hangu sewerage incurred a major delay. The
            wastewater reuse component was cancelled, and the bus
            priority corridors are still at an experiment and planning
            stage. They therefore cost the project considerable delay
            and difficult adjustment efforts.  In fact, it was the
            programmatic element of the project, city sewer and road
            component which consisted of small and medium-size
            subcomponents that allowed an effective adjustment to the
            cancellations while keeping the project consistent with the
            original objectives and framework. Adaptable Program Loan
            (APL) is an instrument that explicitly supports innovations.
            The experience of this project suggests that a combination
            of programmatic and specific investment components could be
            a valid option, while challenge funds or a similar mechanism
            included in programmatic types of projects could be another.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Tianjin Urban Development
            and Environment Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Tianjin
            Urban Development and Environment Project for China is to
            develop and carry out physical and institutional measures
            that would enhance the efficiency and equity of urban
            wastewater management and transportation systems. This
            project is in its seventh year of implementation and has had
            many difficulties.  It was restructured in May 2007.
            Nevertheless its performance declined in 2008 and 2009, the
            main reason being deficiencies in project management and
            coordination during the period when the implementing agency
            the Tianjin Municipal Construction and Administration
            Commission (TCAC) was restructured and replaced with a new
            agency, the Tianjin Municipal Urban Rural Construction and
            Transport Commission (TURCTC). The Ministry of Finance, by
            letter dated February 18, 2011, has requested the following
            changes to the project:  (i) changes to the scope,
            description and location for some components; (ii) extending
            the closing date of the project by 12 months to June 30,
            2012; (iii) reallocating loan proceeds among various
            categories; (iv) increasing the disbursement percentage for
            the works categories to 100 percent  retroactive to June 1,
            2010; and, (v) updating the name of the project implementing
            agency to reflect organizational changes within the Tianjin
            Municipal government.  The changes increase the total
            project cost from US$303.1 million to US$371.4 million. The
            project outcome indicators are not impacted by the changes
            since all components cancelled from the loan have been
            completed using counterpart funding.

China - Second Tianjin Urban
            Development and Environment Project : restructuring (Vol. 2)

repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Tianjin Urban Development
            and Environment Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Second Tianjin Urban Development and Environment Project
            describes how negative environmental impacts will be
            mitigated. Some of them are included here: The maintenance
            of machinery and vehicles will be enhanced to ensure that no
            discharge of black smoke and to strictly comply with the
            city's regulation for motored vehicles. Secondary dust
            raised by construction and transport vehicles will be
            managed by controlling the speed and weight of the vehicles.
            Other dust control measures include water spraying, cleaning
            truck wheels at all entrances and exits, and sweeping
            construction sites. To reduce air pollution, exhaust
            pollutants will be limited and monitored according to
            present regulations. Noise levels near schools, hospitals,
            and residential buildings caused by construction machinery
            and transport vehicles, are short term and temporary and
            will be measured; and if not controlled, especially at
            night, will disturb residents. Noise abatement will include
            reinforcing windows. Temporary bypass measures and
            rearranging public transportation bus lines may ease traffic
            congestion. Discarded soil will be disposed of, cleaned in
            time, and transported to fixed sites. Replanting vegetation
            will reduce soil erosion, lessen traffic dust and noise,
            adjust and improve the road climate, and improve road landscaping.
